body: :shipit: thanks for the fix!

For scalatest, would this be an option?
https://github.com/maiflai/gradle-scalatest/blob/master/README.md
Tried `maiflai/gradle-scalatest` before going with the JUnit integration thing, couldn't get it to work :(
@abesto it looked like a partially implemented sink for spans (as opposed to scribe). Its partial implementation, rotty deps, and lack of any tests say "delete me!"
Thanks for giving this a go, @jamescway! I think once you rebase against upstream master, this gets smaller. I've made some notes, mostly on cleanup.
verified we are only downloading twitter stuff from https://maven.twttr.com
LGTM :rainbow: +1
@abesto, not related at all, :+1: to killing it
rebased
rebasing.. then will merge
+1 let's move it out :-)
:+1: :+1: :+1:  looks like u got everything
@nikhil2406 yoooo this is sweet :+1:
Cool, cool. I'm all for removing dead code.
Tests are now run using maiflai/gradle-scalatest, and some manual tests suggest the whole thing working (see details in description).
Did a cursory review, I might be misunderstanding some things so don't take my comments as blocking or anything like that
Thanks a lot, good points! I'll address them in detail tomorrow.
Thanks, that looks great! +1
Thanks a lot for writing this up, and also the awesome graph :) Definitely +1
:+1: looks great

having some problems after rebase...
traced it down to this line 
`addSbtPlugin("com.twitter" %% "scrooge-sbt-plugin" % "3.19.0")`
previously it was
`addSbtPlugin("com.twitter" %% "scrooge-sbt-plugin" % "3.16.3")`

With the newer lib `sbt publish` now causes: 
`[error] (zipkin-collector-core/*:publish) java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: org.jboss.netty.handler.codec.http.HttpRequest.setHeader(Ljava/lang/String;Ljava/lang/Object;)V
`

here's the full stack trace


Seems like maybe the lib [bintry](https://github.com/softprops/bintry) is using an old version of [dispatch](http://dispatch.databinder.net/Dispatch.html) maybe?
looks like we have netty-3.10.1.Final.jar and async-http-client-1.8.10.jar both loading netty
Where does async-http-client come from? Should be easy to replace with finagle-http if we have control over the source.

Aah, I think I can spot the problem - publish to bintray uses Dispatch, while Scrooge uses Finagle (with an older version of Netty, probably)
I thought sbt used separate class loaders for each plugin, maybe not...

Could an exclude on scrooge work? I doubt the compiler actually needs to
load the netty classes. I can give this a try in 30m or so, if no one else
does.

> @adriancole rolling back and using scrooge-sbt-plugin" % "3.16.3" would
> solve the problem in the meantime
> I'd be fine with adding a commit to use this version with a comment
> about why including the link to the fix. However, it looks like the
> commit didn't change any source files. Another way could be to make a
> commit that overrides the version of dispatch-json4s-native. This
> helps as we already need to update scrooge, and mixed classpath seems
> worse. wdyt?

OK I'm done with the review

I prefer this even as is much more than SBT.

Not blocking, but I feel we should go with conventional gradle vs abbreviations or further normalization.

Ex. fully qualified dependency names vs abbreviations, use resolvers to enforce versions etc. I would optimize more for lower WTF count and higher conventional adoption vs less characters or more effective DRY
Builds fine locally, looks good to me. :shipit:
travis is normal (one JRE passes, other is killed due to megabuild)
I would like to note that this branch is greener than Boston on St Patty's day
Or maybe use 0.8.17?

+1
Maybe Scala 2.11 makes the build faster?
:+1:  but it doesn't seem like its used anywhere?
:+1:  I guess I'll have to rebase 0.3.20 :p
@eirslett sgtm.. is there anything about 0.8.17 that would be incompatible with things? I know Twitter is converging at least initially towards 0.8.14, which was what motivated the change.
it is, just the simple name didn't change, hence not listed in the diff.
don't have strong feelings about mustache versions, updating lgtm :100:

:shipit: with only a couple nits

only one thing surprises me still, which is how the things in anormdb relate to eachother. Then, there's the supernit of tabs? Almost all projects I've seen who have tabs end up in peril due to people spacing to match. FYI, I'm shortly to carve out mongo

I suggest we break out the anormdb thing to a separate issue. Users shouldn't have to recompile to switch the storage they use, but I'd like to keep the scope of this PR minimal.

On tabs: oh my, I just let IntelliJ do whatever it wanted. Spaces incoming.

@abesto wrt anormdb.. it isn't that I want a refactor.. just that the comment `// Database drivers` doesn't explain what's going on. Is there some better context to put in a comment? Right now, it looks like a magic property, which even if is the case, might be able to be explained at least when it is used.
@adriancole plaese check the comments added in https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/commit/e3619a765069c29b15bc2e3f75c906f4f12345fb. I hope that explains what's going on.
@abesto whoot! LGTM
bumping to 0.8.17 as at least scrooge also uses this :)
The implementation looks fine to me. Maybe add some context on why this is happening?
TODO: bump zipkin-web mustache to 0.8.17, remove build files for mongo

Ahh sure. The context is that mongo was a very late merged change. So late, that it is not likely used. Mongo requires a special build (to enable the mongodb service or run locally), and has very little test coverage. Moving this out is reflection that it needs a lot of work, or possible archive.
:star: :+1: :star:
:shipit: :rainbow:
fixed commit message to include rationale.
@abesto so I think you are basically merge-town. might want to consider collapsing commits at this point, yeah? Otherwise this will be perpetually a tracking branch.
Yep, I'll take care of just this last TODO, then squash.
Note: mongo and hbase are currently spun-out as separate repos
@abesto fyi the latest bump on mustache broke the build. you'll want to rebase over this.
merging as the build is broke otherwise. Will take any feedback seriously post-merge.
@taylorleese fyi
I'm going to merge this since the build failures are @adriancole's fault and this change looks like it will dramatically improve everybody's lives :)
This probably isn't going to work now that #503 has been merged <_<
We should be able to revert back to scala-extensions once we're on Scala 2.11.
Or so I think...
OTOH Bintray publishes an official Gradle plugin: https://bintray.com/jfrog/jfrog-jars/gradle-bintray-plugin
See #514
I think @abesto's work moving us over to Gradle in  #503 has helped tremendously. I'm going to close this now
@robbinfan With the new Gradle-based build system that #503 introduced, I believe this issue has been fixed. Will you re-open it if that's not the case?
So green! :shipit:
Other than the typo, :+1:

With the merge of #503, the only potential way that I think this would be a problem is if a user were on a network that was blocking the maven repo. I'm going to close this out.

Please re-open if you can reproduce this error on HEAD of master
+1 for moving redis out!

> Or so I think...
> Tee hee
Is there an alternative way to test this? For example, without literally forking a process?
NOTE: this also deleted the pants files
After update to use gradle https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/503, much of this stuff is not relevant, going to close and start another PR
@abesto just noticed that tool, I'll give it a shot
Mind opening this against the docker-zipkin repo?
No problem

Don't merge, yet.

web is not working correctly via gradle. It seems to be missing something as the response is empty. The old script worked.

``` bash
$ curl -v http://localhost:8080/
* Hostname was NOT found in DNS cache
*   Trying ::1...
* Connected to localhost (::1) port 8080 (#0)
> GET / HTTP/1.1
> User-Agent: curl/7.37.1
> Host: localhost:8080
> Accept: */*
> 
* Empty reply from server
* Connection #0 to host localhost left intact
curl: (52) Empty reply from server
```

@blaines @jamescway PTAL I migrated the base config into gradle.properties. I think the default of "dev" in the two shell scripts is benign enough to leave alone.

I'm still looking into what's wrong with web. Also, sqlite broke some time ago.. I'll try to fix it in this change.
This won't work until #522 is merged. Still looking into what's up with the web script in gradle.
FYI @irff @dsyer @spencergibb
Cool! :+1:
one suggestion but mostly looks fine to me
:shipit:
Tried the whole collector-query-web-tracegen setup locally, works like a charm. Great stuff! :shipit:
thnx for the review @abesto and @spencergibb!

LGTM

@blaines @jamescway heads up! we'll might want to publish these to bintray
@dsyer I'm merging and will let you or someone else add the bundling config file thing later. Good work!
This is a dependency of #194
For now, use `bin/collector` to start the collector. We've updated the readme accordingly. SBT will be removed for gradle soon.

gradle will also address the distribution packaging, too. For example, here's how it is used in docker.

https://github.com/openzipkin/docker-zipkin/blob/master/base/Dockerfile#L7
@adriancole I'll rebase and test it out
yay.. works now! PTAL
Note: I've changed the gradle run config to always start in the build dir. Once we do things like actually creating log files, this should help reduce junk creation.
